Closes #5265.

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

### PR summary [d0639e5c15](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10276/commits/d0639e5c15a0e21577032ff5e9d62d1ec90d9eac)

</details>

<details>

```bash
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
```

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10274~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10293~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19438~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

:v: ericrbg can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

As this PR is labelled `auto-merge-after-CI`, we are now sending it to bors:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12505534100/job/34889044362)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12505534100/job/34889044502)

After addressing the two comments, I don't see why we shouldn't merge. Thanks!

bors d+

After addressing the two comments, I don't see why we shouldn't merge. Thanks!

bors d+

this proof was at 206278 heartbeats before, and went to 230612; I wonder if `Qq` is slow here :/ or maybe just trying to check for positivity is too much. I wonder if it's worth optimising `positivity` so you can also "request" specific things from extensions; in this case it would save a lot of work to not check for `0 < _` unless needed.
I also wonder if it'll get better after the fun_like changes.
this is now 193574 after the FunLike changes :)
Arguably this should be an assertion, since the norm in the expression may not be the canonical one.
I'm not sure when to use what - what's the guidelines?

`assumeInstancesCommute` essentially means "either I know these must always be defeq, or I am happy to produce a totally cryptic error much later in the kernel if they are not". `assertInstancesCommute` means "in rare cases these won't be defeq, so I will spend a little extra work every time checking, so that I can produce a better error".
This shouldn't be needed, you already have a `0` from the `_sng`

```suggestion
      let p â† (â† core q(inferInstance) pE a).toNonzero
```

btw, this comes from a different test that is failing:

```lean
import Mathlib.Tactic.Positivity.Basic

set_option trace.Tactic.positivity true

example {V : Type*} [Zero V] [PartialOrder V] {x : V} (hx : 0 < x) : x â‰  0 := by positivity --fails???
example {V : Type*} [Zero V] [PartialOrder V] {x : V} (hx : 0 < x) : x â‰  0 := ne_of_gt hx
```

I'm not sure why this fails, I'm currently trying to debug but it's annoying to debug tactics.
I fixed this in #10293.
This will conflict with #10196, but not in a major way
Happy to fix it when we merge that:)
What happens if two extensions are registered for the same expression? If both are tried in order, then you could have the weaker one before this lemma, and the stronger one after.
That'd be nice, and I think TC caching should make any issues about things being looked up twice moot. I'll try it out when I get back home
it does indeed go in order
This should probably be an assertion; though it's not clear to me that it is needed at all?
yes, indeed it wasn't - I think it was from when I couldn't figure out the other issue,
This feels rather weird; the order isn't relevant for proving that things are not zero.
We need the `PartialOrder` to call `positivity` on the other subgoal
What I'm challenging here is whether positivity is really an appropriate tool for discharging `v â‰  0` in a vector space
D'oh, of course. I guess `assumption` may be the only reasonable way right now. There is requests for a `nonzero` tactic; maybe I can leave this as a todo

I'm confused how to use `asumption` here; not sure where I could get the right `MVarId` to use `MVarId.assumption`? (I guess the idea is that all the `withContext` stuff is done externally by the main `positivity` tactic, and so maybe I have to write it myself)

I agree here. synthesizing a partial order instance on a vector space is the wrong approach. Are there other examples of `positivity` using assumptions like this, i.e., that aren't themselves just positivity again?
I've changed it to use (a Qq version of) `findLocalDeclWithType?`

```suggestion
is non-zero. Via `norm_pos_iff'`. See `evalAddNorm` for the non-negative case. -/
```

```suggestion
```
Please move these examples to tests.

For the record, I much prefer having the tests near the positivity extension as they demonstrate what the extension can do, are instantaneous to debug and fully cover the behavior of `positivity` on those cases due to the way the tactic is designed, but ok...
Do you want this file in addition to the pre-existing Mathlib.Util.Qq?
Ah thanks! I didn't know about this file

I hope looking at the local context like this doesn't affect any caching that may or may not exist in positivity. (I don't see any.)

This is something that the simp discharger framework has to worry about, when going under binders.

Functions like `evalTriangleRemovalBound` have pre-existing uses of this, so it's likely OK, but I just want to hear confirmation that this is fine.
I can confirm that there is no caching in `positivity` as far as I am aware

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: norm positivity extension proves strict positivity
